title: Recommendations to institutions
text:
- Adopt formal policies requiring/strongly encouraging OS activities.

Institutional prerequisites to enable the practise of OS:

mandate deposit of ALL research outputs (e.g., publications, datasets, code) in the institutional or other compliant repository to be publicly available under an open license (no later than the time of an associated publication, as much as possible), in case of legitimate constraints - ‘dark’* deposit with open metadata. (*) A ‘dark’ deposit (or restricted deposit) is a work in a repository whose full text stays hidden from the public (not OA). However, metadata associated with these deposits is publicly accessible so that authors’ scholarly records are discoverable

mandate for a DMP/software management plan for all research projects, which the staff/postgraduate students are involved in.

require to manage research data in line with the FAIR principles.

ensure that all publications (co)-authored by the staff/postgraduate students contain Data Availability Statements.

encourage that the staff/postgraduate students retain sufficient IP rights to comply with the OA requirements.








Examples of Institutional rights-retention policies





Harvard University, University of Edinburgh




Develop and implement rewarding policies:

boost appreciation of the researchers with good RDM & OS practices with well-documented, FAIR and open digital outputs, in their annual reviews by including OS activities (such as those described in introduction) into the institutional research evaluation scheme.

consider/create performance indicators (quantitative and/or qualitative) in general as well as disciplinary data-level metrics for crediting data sharing in the evaluation schemes.








Best practices examples





EC Open Science Career Assessment Matrix (OS-CAM), TU DELFT Open Science programme, Utrecht University policy on Recognition and Rewards, BIH QUEST programme




promote that non-OA (closed) outputs not be reported for performance evaluation procedures







Best practices examples





CNRS policy




Create data champions schemes.

Create Open Science stamp/badge/label in a PhD Degree Certificate?







Examples





Visibility





- Provide OS capacity building support:

Provide OS courses (as part of the annual mandatory training for research staff and mandatory subjects for postgraduate students).

Organise institutional working groups, workshops.

Provide digital training materials, newsletters.







Examples





Best practices & resources training, UNESCO’s index




Establish dedicated human resources/units, such as data stewards & managers, and engage libraries.







Best practice





TU Delft Data Stewardship project and Data Champions initiative, CNRS DDOR





- Provide infrastructure and material resources for OS

Provide or work with a trusted repository







Best practice





Repository certification based on CoreTrustSeal, Nestor Seal DIN31644 or ISO16363 (see the EC’s expectations for trusted repositories in the Horizon Europe Annotated Model Grant Agreement, pp. 155-156), CNRS DDOR




Provide digital services & tools (e.g., DMP tool; FAIR data management, anonymisation, analysis tools)



- Provide financial support for OS:

Costs related to PIDs, such as DOIs, registration for all research outputs, including datasets.
APCs (excluding hybrid journals), transformative agreement costs.

Costs associated with research data/software management.

Investments in national/regional OS initiatives, such as Diamond OA initiatives (if any).



- Create other types of rewards

Co-work chances with related OS groups and people.

Free time (sabbatical time).

Gifts.

Salary bonus.

title: Guidance about how to best recognise Open Science (OS) activities or to promote recognition, at various levels
text:
Important



Be aware that this is a working document. Want to contribute?
The first section (A) guides researchers on practices they should adopt to maximise their recognition for their open science efforts. Sections (B-F) include recommended mechanisms that funders, institutions, evaluation committees, publishers can follow.

title: Guidance about how to best recognise Open Science (OS) activities or to promote recognition, at various levels
text:
Examples of OS activities

preregistration of the study design, methods, hypothesis, etc. prior to commencing the research
sharing a research manuscript/preprint (as the first step of a peer-review process)
publishing a paper or monograph/book as Open Access
making research data open and FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable)
making the code (e.g., software, models, algorithms, workflows) openly available
open peer review (e.g., being reviewed or the reviewer)
outreach and public engagement in science, including citizen science
teaching/training open science

title: Recognition at the individual level
section: Maximise your visibility citation out of your open science work
text:
Maximise your visibility citation out of your open science work

Pre-requisite on digital presence:


Maximise as much as possible your digital presence using PID for you and for all your outputs (ex/ ORCID, DOI or other identifier for OA publications / OA datasets/ Open source software. Example: Parsec Digital Presence checklist | Unesco.
Update your cv & reporting activities with your OS activites.


Make your data & outputs citable


Include citation elements for research data/software you created in the References section of your paper. To support indexing and reuse:

Use American Psychological Association (APA) style.

Include a persistent identifier (DOI), preferred, or URL.

Use labels/bracketed descriptions (e.g., [Dataset], [Software], [Collection], [ComputationalNotebook]).


Include a data/software availability statement in your paper that describes where and how your data are available, and how to cite them if possible. Refer to templates for detailed information. Example: AGU


Acknowledge OS contributorship


Recognise all kind of contributorship early in the projects. Example: Acknowledging Contributors - The Turing Way

Use the CRediT taxonomy:

Allocate the terms appropriately to your own contribution and to contributors within research outputs.

Advocate that your institution and any publications you’re submitting to acknowledge and adopt the taxonomy. Example: Implementing CRediT



Cite or acknowledge other’s OS activities using DOis or other PIDs


Include data citations for all research data you used in the References section of your paper.

Acknowledge any OS tool you may use , e.g. with their identifier or ‘How to cite’ statement (if any). More information: RDA WG

title: Recognition at the individual level
text:
Get financial reward or support

Apply to specific funds for OS activities if any.

Apply to OS prize/awards if any.
Anticipate an OS budget in your research funding applications.
